content:
Time was too short for shortest mode.
Did not had time to finish my solution:

c=int(input()[1:],16)
i,j=0,0
while c:c,r=divmod(c,256);i*=2;j*=2;i+=r>9;j+=r>244
print(['white',['black','red','green','yellow','blue','magenta','cyan','grey'][i]][j<7])

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It has a simple solution, but is not immediately solved.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It seems easy enough for clashing, is fun and teaches something about RGB encoding

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is well-written and helps coders improve their management of if, else and else if statements.

I like it, it's an original idea. Maybe it would be simpler if the colour codes were already in the RGB format so that the players may go straight into making the "fun" part of the program (hexadecimal to decimal conversion is something that most coders know how to do, and plus there are functions such as int("FF", 16) in Python that instantly give the decimal value). All in all, it definitely seems Clash of Code worthy!
